title: Synthetic Recap
body:
BOSTON – In the hallowed halls of the Boston Garden, history was not made by the home team, but by a singular force of nature wearing Sacramento purple. Mitch Richmond didn’t just beat the Celtics; he authored a masterpiece, pouring in a career-high 47 points to carry the Kings to a stunning 111-105 victory.

From the opening tip, Richmond was unstoppable. He carved through the Celtics’ defense with a breathtaking array of moves, hitting from deep, mid-range, and attacking the rim with ferocious intent. The Celtics, helpless to find an answer, could only watch as he piled up the points. His 47-point eruption was not merely a high-scoring night; it was a historic, career-defining performance that left an indelible mark on the 1997 season.

While Richmond’s scoring barrage was the headline, he was not entirely alone. Olden Polynice provided a crucial, rock-solid presence inside, controlling the glass with 16 rebounds and adding 10 points for a double-double. His work in the paint afforded Richmond the space to operate and ensured the Kings held their own against a physical Celtics squad.

Boston fought valiantly, led by Rick Fox’s 24 points and Antoine Walker’s 21, but they simply had no counter for the hurricane named Mitch Richmond. On this night, he was the best player on the planet, and the Kings were wise to simply get out of his way and ride the wave of his legendary performance to a memorable road triumph.
